civilopediaText.text: Food Consumption is a core mechanic that determines how your armies and population sustain themselves.
Units and Heroes: Every military unit and hero consumes food each turn based on their size and type. Larger armies require more food to maintain.
City Population: Each citizen in your cities also consumes 2 food per turn to survive and grow.
Garrison Units: Troops stationed in city garrisons consume food from the city's food production, reducing the surplus available for population growth.
Food Sources: Cities generate food from worked tiles (farms, pastures, fishing boats), trade routes, and certain buildings like granaries.
Consequences of Food Shortage: If a city cannot produce enough food for its population and garrison, the city will start losing population, and stationed troops may disband or lose effectiveness.
Managing Food: Balance your military needs with city growth by building food improvements, managing garrison sizes, and planning army movements to avoid overextending supply lines.
Armies are groups of military units that can be managed together and moved as cohesive forces.
Army Composition: Each army can contain multiple types of troops with different strengths, abilities, and roles in combat.
Hero Leadership: Heroes can lead armies, providing combat bonuses and special abilities to the troops under their command.
Troop Types: Different unit types (Spearmen, Archers, Cavalry, etc.) have unique combat roles and resource requirements.
Splitting and Combining: You can split large armies into smaller forces or combine multiple armies for major campaigns.
Supply and Movement: Armies require supply lines and consume food while moving. Consider logistics when planning military campaigns.
City Garrisons provide defense for your cities but require food and maintenance to sustain.
Garrison Capacity: Each city can support a limited number of garrison troops based on its population and infrastructure.
Food Consumption: Garrisoned units consume food from the city's production, reducing the food available for population growth.
Defensive Benefits: Garrison troops automatically defend the city when attacked and provide a defensive bonus to city combat strength.
Unit Training: Cities can train new military units, which are automatically added to the garrison if space is available.
Managing Garrisons: Balance defense needs with economic growth by adjusting garrison sizes based on threat levels and available food.
Heroes are special units that can lead armies and provide unique abilities and bonuses to your military forces.
Hero Abilities: Each hero has unique skills, combat bonuses, and special abilities that can turn the tide of battle.
Army Leadership: Heroes can command armies, providing leadership bonuses and coordinating troop movements.
Experience and Growth: Heroes gain experience through combat and can level up to unlock new abilities and improved stats.
Resource Consumption: Like other units, heroes consume food and may require special resources for their abilities.
Strategic Value: Heroes are valuable assets that should be protected while maximizing their impact on military operations.
